Class BakeOptions.Builder

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.varmateo.yawg.api.BakeOptions.Builder
  • Enclosing interface:
    BakeOptions

    public static final class BakeOptions.Builder
extends Object
    A builder of BakeOptions instances.

        public BakeOptions.Builder putExternalPageVars(String key,
                                               Object value)
        Associates key with value in the map to be returned from BakeOptions.externalPageVars(). If the map previously contained a mapping for the key, the old value is replaced by the specified value.
        Returns:
        this Builder object
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if either key or value are null

      • mutateExternalPageVars

        public BakeOptions.Builder mutateExternalPageVars(Consumer<? super Map<String,Object>> mutator)
        Invokes mutator with the map to be returned from BakeOptions.externalPageVars().

        This method mutates the map in-place. mutator is a void consumer, so any value returned from a lambda will be ignored. Take care not to call pure functions, like Collection.stream().

        Returns:
        this Builder object
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if mutator is null

      • clearExternalPageVars

        public BakeOptions.Builder clearExternalPageVars()
        Removes all of the mappings from the map to be returned from BakeOptions.externalPageVars().
        Returns:
        this Builder object

      • externalPageVars

        public Map<String,Object> externalPageVars()
        Returns an unmodifiable view of the map that will be returned by BakeOptions.externalPageVars(). Changes to this builder will be reflected in the view.

      • buildPartial

        public BakeOptions buildPartial()
        Returns a newly-created partial BakeOptions for use in unit tests. State checking will not be performed. Unset properties will throw an UnsupportedOperationException when accessed via the partial object.

        The builder returned by BakeOptions_Builder.from(BakeOptions) will propagate the partial status of its input, overriding build() to return another partial. This allows for robust tests of modify-rebuild code.

        Partials should only ever be used in tests. They permit writing robust test cases that won't fail if this type gains more application-level constraints (e.g. new required fields) in future. If you require partially complete values in production code, consider using a Builder.
